awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Global Transport Markets: Impact on World Trade and Efficiency
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER agenda looks at the role of the transportation sector in world trade. Using novel data sources, the research addresses questions on the role of geography, tariffs and trade barriers, improvements in ship fuel efficiency and new infrastructure developments on transportation prices and trade flows. The research looks at the efficiency of transportation sector and how social welfare can be improved through appropriate policies. The research also considers the impact of a centralizing platform, like Uber.
 
The project develops a spatial model that centers on the interaction of the market for (oceanic) transportation services and the market for world trade in goods. The model delivers equilibrium trade flows, as well as equilibrium trade costs. This setup is then used to demonstrate that the transportation sector (i) implies that net exporters (importers) face higher (lower) trade costs leading to misallocation of productive activities across countries; (ii) creates network effects in trade costs; and (iii) dampens the impact of shocks on trade flows. These three mechanisms reveal a new role for geography in international trade. Next, the research explores both theoretically and empirically the efficiency properties of equilibria in decentralized transportation markets and suggest appropriate policies for the improvement of world welfare. The research also introduces a micro-founded trade cost in the canonical trade model in order to examine its welfare properties. The project then will investigate the role of (maritime) infrastructure on growth and world trade.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Transport markets are vital for economic activity. Yet how they shape trade flows and costs remains largely unexplored. Given the increasing importance of world trade, the role of the transportation sector becomes central in everyday life. This was most apparent recently during the COVID-19 disruptions.
Through this NSF-CAREER-SES-1847555 award, I explore the role of the transportation sector in world trade, as well as its efficiency properties. What is the role of geography in determining trade costs and flows? How do chokepoints such as the Suez Canal impact trade costs and flows? How do shocks, such as a Chinese slow-down or an oil price shock, propagate through the network of countries? Are transport markets efficient and if not, what policies would improve societal welfare? What would be the impact of a centralizing platform, like Uber? I focus on oceanic shipping, transporting more than 80% of world trade (in tons). 
Our first project develops a rich quantitative model of the market for transportation services. Using big data from the bulk shipping industry (carrying mostly commodities and raw materials) we study how the interaction between the market for transport services and the market for world trade in goods shapes trade flows, trade costs, the propagation of shocks, and the allocation of productive activities across countries. Consider a simple example: shipping from Australia to China is 30% more expensive than the reverse: as China imports raw materials, ships arriving there have limited opportunities to reload. This phenomenon is pervasive in most, if not all modes of transportation: trucks, trains, container air/ocean shipping, all exhibit similar price asymmetries. In fact, the US-China trade deficit in manufacturing has incentivized US exports of low value cargo, such as scrap, to fill up empty backhauls.
We employ AIS data that track ship positions in real time, as well as their sea submergence, informing us whether they are loaded. We document that: (i) there is substantial imbalance in the world trade for commodities and thus empty trips are common (42% of ships travel empty at any point in time); (ii) the net export position is an important determinant of a country's trade costs; (iii) transport costs have a substantial impact on trade.
We then combine the data with a dynamic spatial model for transportation and trade. We use this framework to illustrate the importance of endogenous trade costs and perform policy analysis. We compare our setup to a more standard one with exogenous trade costs and we then explore the impact of a fuel cost shock, a slow-down in China, the opening of the Northwest Passage due to ice melting, and the closure of important chokepoints (Suez, Panama, Gibraltar).
These experiments demonstrate that the transportation sector (i) attenuates differences in the comparative advantage across countries, reallocating production from net exporters to net importers; (ii) creates network effects in trade costs; and (iii) dampens the impact of shocks on trade flows. These three mechanisms reveal a new role for geography in international trade that was previously shrouded by the common assumption of exogenous trade costs. 
In our second project, we provide a theoretical and empirical analysis of efficiency in decentralized transport markets. A substantial fraction of transport markets are decentralized; lacking a central market place, they feature a fragmented structure, with a large number of agents meeting and trading in ad hoc fashion. This is the case for taxis, trucking, oceanic bulk shipping, as well as bike/motorcycle taxis. These markets suffer from search frictions, i.e. impediments to trade arising from the meeting process. Are transport agents suboptimally allocated over space, distorting transportation flows? And if so, which policies are best at restoring the optimality of the transport network? Can a centralizing platform perform better? In recent years, these questions have captured the interest of policymakers. 
In our theoretical analysis, we identify the externalities that stem from search frictions and distort transportation flows. Importantly, we derive the optimal prices, or taxes/subsidies. We find that destination-based pricing is essential to attain efficiency. 
We again use the AIS data to show that frictions lead to substantially lower trade. Recently, platforms have emerged as a market-based solution to search frictions: by centralizing transactions, they can improve market efficiency. Ideally, centralization would coincide with the frictionless equilibrium. However, a centralizing platform does not act like a benevolent planner: it chooses prices to maximize profits, thus substituting one friction (search frictions) for another (market power). We find that indeed the increase in welfare achieved by the platform is substantially lower than what is achieved in the frictionless equilibrium. The gains are appropriated to a large extent by the platform as profits. Strikingly, we find that our optimal policy can achieve the same increase in welfare, by levying the optimal taxes. In contrast to the platform, now the welfare gains are redistributed to the market agents.
